And thirdly, just on Sensis, really very good result, particularly on the White Pages, I know you've talked about it a little bit, but can you just give us a bit of a sense of exactly what's driving that? Is it increased use of color or how are you getting that growth in the print business?

And just on the Sensis, just wondering if you could give a sense of whether there's a vast difference between the regional and metro print publications? I guess, I'm trying to get a sense of whether the online penetration in regional markets has made any difference to your print businesses.

Okay. Let me start off on the first one, then I'll pass to John on the margins, because he – I think he'll give you a better sense of the margins. Firstly, I said the balance between share and profitability is what we're managing. For example, there was enormous subsidies in the market around iPhone for the last six months. We took a considered view about what our subsidies were in the market. And as you saw, SACs are down, and we are very carefully managing that.

Now, we do think that the whole proposition around PDAs is very strong. But we're going to have a balanced view about that as we go forward, because we have learned over the years, even back to when I ran the Mobiles group, you can get a bit carried away with just driving top line growth. However, so when you look at our results, 10% growth at the revenue line and our tremendous growth in terms of subscribers, 33% of data, this group was up. Now, in terms of the margins, John?

Yes. The margins have grown. Mobile margin is about 37% EBITDA margins. And last year, I think we probably totalled over 36%. We've actually got a far better economic model to work out margins these days. And probably, we're a little bit overstated last year. So in actual effect, the margins have grown more than 1% '08 '09, '07 '08, but they are at 37% now so – and have grown.

So just to answer your question, it's all about balance going forward, but as I -- we do not want that share to get away on us. So we'll just manage it carefully as we go forward month-by-month, quarter-by-quarter. And that's the wonderful thing about some of these new systems and the retail out is we are getting better at doing that as we go forward.

In terms of HFC, yeah, we are committed to that rollout. We have got the team working on it now and we're excited about seeing what we can drive from HFC. We've got some good product fill, maybe just putting 100 megs out there really doesn't mean a whole lot. You've got to have things for it to use, changes the experience. So we are committed to that roll out and we think it's going to be exciting to watch and see how it performs. And we've got some good plans in that area.
Now in terms of Sensis, let me ask Bruce to comment because Bruce is out there, hustling on the streets every day and so Bruce why don't you give some colour to that?

Look it's a great product that customers love. Everyone is using it. And we have spent a lot of time being able to explain that value proposition to customers. So there hasn't been any particular magic about it other than really understanding what that value proposition is, how we bring buyers and sellers together. And how – if you want to be in business in Australia, whether it's in metro or regional small business, you've got to be in the Yellow Pages. And if you are in the Yellow Pages, you are then online, you're then in mobiles, you're then on 1234, you are then in MSN's Bing, we've now done a syndication arrangement with Google. We have increased the reach of your yellow advertising by about 25% over the last 12 months. So it's a much, much stronger value proposition.

In terms of how the particular products within that portfolio performed in the last financial year, Yellow Metro was slightly negative, Yellow Regional was slightly positive, White Metro was quite strongly positive and White Regional was not quite as strongly positive.

So we are seeing solid maintenance of the print products overall. Overall print was positive but the metro areas were under pressure, but the growth that we are seeing is coming from all of the product extensions into these new digital formats.

Thanks Bruce. Yeah I just want to add just a -- maybe an editorial commentary. I have been incredibly impressed. I didn't know the Sensis business as well. But the level of sophistication that they have when they talk to a customer about the value that that print product drives is quite outstanding and what's different to just putting an ad in the paper or putting just something out there on the fly is we can track the response rate and therefore the return.

I don't know many other products that can do that and that has been the incredible difference we've seen in Sensis over the last two years and I think that's great credit to the team. You don't – it seems great, it sells excellent. So just I think a great result. So I hope that answers on the HFC, that upgrade on the HFC, I think we've covered that. Okay.
We'll get a couple more questions from the line please.
Our next question is from Mark Blackwell from Morgan Stanley.

Hi, guys. I have two questions on wireless broadband. It's great growth in subs of course, but it's come at the expense of ARPU, which is obviously what most would have expected given the $80 you were getting before. But is 62 or thereabouts, kind of what, you were expecting it to settle at? Or should we expect that to continue to fall or what is -- what's your view on that product and where the pricing will go?

Let me make a few quick comments and then I'll pass to John because he's got the detail. You know, look – there's been a number of factors. Yeah maybe we put out a prepaid product this year that definitely pulls that ARPU down, maybe price competition. Well we think we're getting into the right ballpark it will be a matter of the mix. We obviously are focused on driving contracted customers as we go forward, we think the prepaid product is good. So around that, John, do you want to comment on that?

It's primarily driven by going into prepaid wireless broadband. It's been proven very popular and obviously the mix change has changed the ARPU. If it continues to be as popular as this, yeah, it can go down a bit further.

Yeah I agree, I mean it is a wonderful proposition there is now up to a million subs now which is great and we are looking forward to seeing that grow and of course, we still think there's lots of life left in that Next G network as we go forward.
The last question from the line please?

Well, just on the – the kind of balancing to that is that more and more smart phones will come into the market and so you'll have more take up of wireless broadband, so absolute growth will still be strong.
Next question comes from Sachin Gupta from Nomura.
Yes, thanks very much. I have two questions. Firstly is it possible to get could you give us a rough number for EBITDA – 500 say, and I was just wondering if you sort of quantify that .

Secondly, on the new presentation slide, they're saying, the reconcilitaion slide, it looks like the revenue growth and the EBITDA – revenue growth and the expense growth is pretty much in line with previous target. But the EBITDA growth is only 1 to 2.5% so thinking what happened there, what are the drivers there?

And lastly David, you mentioned a number of times that protecting shareholder value in any discussion with the government, obviously management has talked about the of around 18% previously. I was just wondering is that still the basis for discussions for the new network, please? Thanks.
Okay. We missed the first question. Do you want to repeat the first question?
Yes, Sachin, can you repeat the first question please?
We missed them.
Okay.
We will just take the – we'll take the second and third questions.
Okay. You take the second question.
Okay.
Did you --
No, I didn't quite get the second question, that was the reconciliation one.
Okay. I did not get it.
Would you like to repeat the question?
The third question around the ---
The third question I got.
The second question was around the trends in the EBITDA growth in 2010 being somewhat below prior expectations, and the explanation for that?

Yeah, well, I think I went through it in my presentation that we've had this DVC mix change or product mix change which has increased the directly variable costs. And so – and then when you have, you pay . And that being a high margin product set then that's what's happened to EBITDA margins. The growth in EBITDA has also been impacted by the cost explanation that I just went through. EBITDA growth would have been greater had there not been a delay in the cost of IT transformation realization. So all those things have accumulated, if you like, into the EBITDA growth and the EBITDA margin situation.

The third question, about 18% return, look, we haven't – we are a long way off discussing what detail of NBN might look like. And at the end of the day, and you might have picked up in our tone today and what David has said, and what I have said, that it's – this about protecting shareholder value. And in protecting shareholder value that could mean – a return that actually results in that protection. So we aren't locked into the numbers is what I am really saying.
Thank you. We will come back here to Sydney. Phil, hopefully we can hear you question.
It's Phil Campbell from Citigroup, just a couple of questions for David.
Yeah.

The first one was, I just want to try and check from the presentation this morning, I am kind of picking up probably three subtle, but important changes since you've taken over. The first one is obviously a greater emphasis on customer service. The second one is this focus on market share or end margin mix and the last one is obviously the NBN, where you are actually talking more friendly with the government. So the first question, I just want to check whether there are any others that may I have missed, or if those are the three ones that you think are valid?

The second question is just, may be you can give us a little bit more information on the first two. So in terms of customer service, is that a case of customer service levels have declined to quite a bad point, or is that a case of trying to make sure the service levels are at a high level as we go into NBN environment?

The other question is on this margin, on the market share mix. I kind of understand the background for that, but again like in mobile you'd think with Hutch and Voda doing a merger, you might have actually thought the opposite and thought maybe you'd be more aggressive in that space. So a little bit more background around those two things would be great.

Okay. Well, in terms of subtle messages, I was trying not to be so subtle, customer service is critically important. Now you say, why? It's – when you go through a big transformation, there's always impacts. But this is something that is at the heart of what we do. Remember the number of customer interactions every day, and our front of house, in terms of field technicians, we think this is an incredible opportunity to really differentiate. Now, but before I go there and talk a little bit more, the only one you've missed in terms of the first three was product differentiation. This is – and the integration across Next-G and Next IP. This is very important and has been a continuak theme. So that is four, it's actually more than three, it's four.

Then coming at customer service, so, yeah if you've seen the TIO complaints in our industry, not just Telstra, our industry has gone up. Our share of the complaints going to the ombudsman are about the same. But we've got far too many. I think if you go back over 5 to 6 years, it's been a significant increase. That's not good for our industry. It's not good for Telstra, it's not good for our customers. And I'm not going to put up with it. And let me also say, I do not need an ombudsman to handle our customers. It is such an indictment on our industry and on Telstra. So, that's the reason and but more than that, if I can reduce churn and I can differentiate, you know the numbers: every customer you save, it's far better than trying to acquire one. So, we're about reducing churn, and if we can hold our customers longer, that is good for our shareholders. So very simple.

Now the second one was around the share – the mix segment. Yeah, I'm not quite sure how to answer that one in the sense that that's always been a priority for us. In fact, when we've talked about differentiation and value, we've always been very considered about that mix. Maybe it's got a little bit more prevalent now, because we've seen people putting a lot of money into the market to try to – attract subs and we're conscious not to fall into that trap.

That doesn't mean we don't want to be competitive, we don't want to have a premium around value that is justifiable and clearly articulated, and we will move with the market. But it is a very considered mix, and we've learnt over the years to be better and better at this by every day, by every week, by every month and that's what I think is probably the bigger change. So at any one time, we'll see sort of up and down, but we're about profitable revenue growth, profitable revenue growth. So I hope that gives you some colour and we can talk more about it as we go forward.
We got four more hopefully very quick questions from the floor. We need to move on to the media calls. Mark?

Yes good morning, well done on the results and if I may say also congratulations on a far more credible set of forecasts, particularly around the EBITDA margin. Three areas I'd like to touch on briefly: revenue, OpEx and CapEx. On the revenue side, I was wondering if you could be a little more specific about the composition from new services into your growth expectation and in particular into the second half. Presumably by then, the DOCSIS 3 upgrade is complete and we should see a range of new products coming through, particularly in broadband. So what proportion of your revenue growth guidance is contributed to from new services?
Yep, do you want to give us all three?

All right, in relation to OpEx, you've spoken about further head count reductions, I'm wondering if you can quantify that? Also in relation to the cost overruns in the IT transformation program, my understanding from speaking to IT people at Telstra is that there are still major issues. There are certain functions in Siebel, for example, that take five long – five times as long to perform as in the old legacy systems. What are your expectations about the future dimensions of cost overrun, what sort of contractual protections do you have, and what is the magnitude of that in the year ahead? And then that leads to my third question, which is more CapEx related, and that is actually about where we are in the CapEx cycle?

And in particular, what is implied by the technology transformations that have occurred, and the substitution of purchased equipment for leased equipment, and in particular are we seeing a truncation of the CapEx cycle? So while everyone is focused at the moment on a reduction in FY10, as we go forward, the replacement times, for a lot of the network and IT equipment and software, may in fact be much shorter than historically, can you comment on that?

Okay. Let me have a go at the revenue one, and then I will get little bit color from John as well. Firstly, your supposition that we have got to drive more from the new products is right. The flow through of that into the specific numbers, we probably need to come back to you and give you some color. We do have a lot of focus on how to drive out from the HFC upgrade, but also some of these integrated products, in the terms of the home of the future and also the business of the future. And I said, driving that growth from off the platforms is critically important. We are sort of in the mid 40s, we think that's going to go significantly up as we go forward.

So, yes, very important. Also, some of the managed services areas as well are important, also in terms of content. I think, do you have any specific numbers John, because I don't have it off the top of my head.

No. I mean, we are excepting, obviously we are expecting growth in the newer products that we have today, wireless broadband and so on. But I don't have a proportion of the growth going forward off the top of my head.
Why don't we, we can probably come back and sort of – we just haven't done that calculation. But obviously, you have got PSTN is going to go down, we got to keep driving that up.

Then let's talk about the OpEx head count on IT transformation, and let me have a go at it, and if the guys down in the front might be able to help me out, they can. Firstly, look, we are not giving any guidance specifically on head count. But I do want to stress that this business is always moving.

We're a technology company. We're about using technology to drive productivity. Therefore, we are very focused on how we can drive productivity or the skills mix is the other thing, because we are seeing some of the old skills we don't need. I mean, especially this, as we start to move people more online, what we are going to do with the people who have traditionally taken calls? So yes, we do expect, over time, to drive productivity improvement, we must do. That's at our heart. But where we are sort of – we did forecast, what was it – was it 12,000 people out – 10 to 12. We're not putting forecasts out there, but let me assure you, our focus on productivity remains as strong and as vigilant as ever.

Now in terms of the wonderful Siebel roll out, look, I'm going to share a little bit of experience here and then John or David might want to comment. A lot of people ask me about Enterprise and Government. Well, why do they come across here – and I tell you why, because we did it in 2002. We put Siebel in, no one had somehow managed to, so think about it, but we did it. I can remember what happened. We put it in, and the first release was an absolute failure. The way we had to pull it out and put back in, and I think it took us something like 15 months of just working every application, trying to get the processes right, some instantaneous benefits from. And some took us a good while because we had to redefine the way we did the transaction.

Siebel is a wonderful product. It gives you a look of flexibility which – but it takes time for people to get the value from. So I'm not concerned about driving the value from Siebel deployment at all, absolutely not. I think it will take us time and that's partly what we're affected. I don't think there's any necessity for any recourse to anyone, because we are going to drive the value from the product. But it just takes time. And when people stand up and say, you drop a new release in of CRM and you get instantaneous business, well, it's just not true. So that's where we are focused. So, no, we do not have any recourse to anyone. David, do you want to put any colour or John? Because these are the guys who are doing it and they're running it all every day.

Mark, the average handling time for an agent to serve a customer changed a little bit through the deployment as people got used to it. It was as big a change as we're ever going to in any 10 to 15 year period of time at front-of-house. So everyone had to be re-trained in all new processes while we were simultaneously migrating customers et cetera, et cetera. There are certainly a couple of things that might be up and down in terms of the relative individual components of how you serve a customer. But overall, our average handling times are trending right back down to where we want them to be, and they are right on track. So with that comes the benefits that we need.

But as David has indicated, the focus is now in investing on the customer experience, solving their problem first time, making those kind of changes. The Siebel system helps us enormously to do that because we can see the entire customer record in one place. And we can serve the customer for all of their needs, which we couldn't do before. So this is definitely a major step forward for the company and for the customers particularly, as a result of what we are doing, and for our agents.

And I will finish with the comment that we did a survey, a pulse survey, of our employees through the middle of this, which was for us to test how things were going, and employee engagement went up 2%. So from my point of view, I'm totally satisfied that we haven't yet finished all of the benefits that are going to come from the releases that are yet to conclude. But once we put the whole package together, it's going to be a terrific result for our employees, our customers, and ultimately the shareholder.

Mark, let me quickly, just another editorial comment. One of the great things we know is done is that the benefits from the CRM now sit with David. So in his plan for this year and for next year, he has to realize the benefits, both in customer service and in the productivity benefits. So I don't want to just leave it out there, it's difficult, it's not straightforward. So I – we still lot of work to do to get it better there and get the real value, but now the work starts. John, do you want to talk about capital?

I will. I just have another comment about IT, we're all experts in IT. But on the cost front, you made the comment about cost overrun, what I commented on, realization of benefits. But and there's lots of rumors out about cost overrun. In October, I'm going to take you all through how much CapEx and sweepstake and where. There are things in this IT transformation program and spend that when we started, weren't in there. For example, Big Pump wasn't in the transformation, and now it is. That took some more money. So there is a whole lot of things that I will go through to detail the spend. And it will become clear to you that this isn't – and yeah, there is a little bit more complexity. Yeah, we did spend some more money as we come to the realization of the more complexity. But I'll take you through that in October.

CapEx, life cycle and so on. We foresee over the next few years to be around 14% CapEx to sales. And as sales goes up, that means therefore the CapEx will go up slightly. And we think that that we will cope with what I would call a normal evolution.

Now, let's say LTE comes along well, all right, or 4G Mobile or whatever you want to call it. There will be a kick up. There is no doubt about that. And there may be a time when there are other technologies that come along that cause a kicker, but right now, the next few years and LTE is not tomorrow or next year, might be not the next year after that. So over the next three years I'm confident about our 14% CapEx to sales. But you are right – there will be some technology life cycles that give a kicker in the CapEx as always happens in this industry, by the way.
Sorry, just to clarify, so that's 14% for the next three years John?

Yeah, and that's what I have said, around 14%. I said I am confident unless something comes. If LTE has to come forward for some reason, I'm wrong – but failing that sort of thing happening, it should be around that.
Thank you.
Okay.

Hi, guys. Laurent Horrut, JPMorgan. Just had a question. And given your EBIT growth guidance now and assuming sort of, you don't have single IFRS adjustment in 2010. And am I right, do you think that your impact could actually be sort of flat from under 4.1 you just reporting?
I am not expecting it to be flat, but I am not expecting to be as high as it is this year.
Okay. I guess, just on the IFRS adjustments, do you expect them to, you're reporting 900 million interest cost this year, you know, normalized level would probably be more like 1.1. So what is...
The debt maturities – well, as they wind out...right
Yeah.
Your favourable gain, fair value gain will decline, and so next year, the gain will be less and less as we as we get profile...

So we should trend back to 1.1. Okay. And a very quick second question. I guess it's looking back at the transformation plan, when you, when it was outlined five years ago, there were three objectives: revenue growth, acceleration, OpEx reduction and CapEx reduction. And I guess, it will be hard to argue that you haven't been successful in the revenue growth acceleration objective. So we'll give you full marks for that. It's less clear to me what is actually delivered in terms of structural benefits on the OpEx on the cost base and on the CapEx side because I do remember years where Telstra was actually spending only 14% of sales. And I do remember that in 2005 the margins were 47%. So I'm just looking for – I think we spent 5, 6 billion of incremental CapEx above what should have been spent, would have be spent otherwise. What are the actual structural benefits that are going to sort of last beyond 2010?

Let me give a perspective of this, John can comment. I think you're right, I think we're yet to see the flow through of the benefits from some of the IT transformation. But remember, next year mixed IP enormous value in terms of just the operations in that business, there's been a lot of value. But in terms of the IT transformation we're yet to see the flow through. We've done a lot of investment training, getting people to get used to these new systems, new bills – I mean, it's an enormous job. When you put a new release of the software out, the incredible amount work of just looking every plan, every iteration. So we, as John said, we think that is delayed, and we think it's out in the future, but we had no option. We had no option. It was as the businesses was getting more complicated, the systems were getting harder and harder to manage, too many legacy systems. We had to do it. But yes, we've now got to drive the benefits up. So, still work in progress.
Thank you.
Andrew.

Yeah. Andrew Levy, Macquarie. Just a quick one of the functional separation slide, could you just give us an idea on for the BT and the telecom New Zealand models, what's implementation versus ongoing operational impacts, if you had to split it percentage-wise, so like CapEx versus OpEX?

No, it's a separate factor. The latter is not factored in. The large functional separation, we saw a range from an adjudicator, which is – was part of a solution and then you could sort have the adjudicator plus transfer pricing, you could have the adjudicator plus transferred pricing plus petition systems. And as you go up that – both forms of separation cost you more and it takes you longer. The $0.04 or 500 million that I talked about, the $0.04 NPV is down at the bottom end. We have some petitioned systems, right. So, it's transferred pricing, it's – we hadn't thought of an adjudicator back then, so it's quite a light touch. And then you can get right up to the other end, a very expensive, unwinding of the IT systems in order that you've got complete separation. I mean that's what I'd say, much below not a lot of time.

The bigger ones. Yeah, the full-on sort of – I'll give you a range. 800 billion, right, and ongoing 50 to 100, right, so it's in five to six years.

That's a good question. Firstly, I'm primarily focused on getting rid of the unnecessary work. I think there is too many repeat calls coming into the business, too many transfers, we are having to respond to too much, so I think there is enormous opportunity to reduce work, in sort of the 5 to 10% type range. That's work element as you go forward. But the critical thing is if you can just move churn by 0.1, 0.2% the benefits to us go straight to the bottom line.

So now the sorts of things. I don't need to move churn very much to get an enormous benefit. We are still working though some of it but we've got some internal targets, which we've set but now we will see that may be we will talk about that at the end of the year, but very important, this is not just a nice feel good thing, may be one business results for us.
